description: From Middle English rydyng; equivalent to ride +‎ -ing.

entries.meaning: The act of one who rides; a mounted excursion.
examples: I like nothing better than to hear of your ridings, and shootings, and boatings.

entries.meaning: The behaviour in the motion of a vehicle, such as oscillation.

description: From trithing (initial /t/ absorbed into preceding north, south, east, west, inner ‘th’ already sometimes /d/ in Middle English), from Middle English trithing, tridinge, from Old English *þriðing, from Old Norse þriðjungr (“third part”), from Proto-Germanic *þridjô (“third”) (English third). Equivalent to third +‎ -ing; compare with farthing (“fourth part”). Cognate with English trithing.
The folk etymology that connects the term to the area a horse-rider could cover in a single day is incorrect, but may have influenced the spelling and pronunciation.

entries.meaning: (historical) Any of the three administrative divisions of Yorkshire and some other northern counties of England.
